This was before the Broadway musical "Dreamgirls" pumped up similar material for its own purposes.Now comes the "Sparkle" remake and you know what? It works. The director is Salim Akil whose ensemble comedy "Jump the Broom" likewise paced itself with ease and authority and showed similar wiles in the way of cliche refurbishment. Most of the stuff thats new in the new "Sparkle" written by Mara Brock Akil (who is married to the director) is shrewd and cleverly considered. The stuff thats old is what people responded to back in 76.The action steered more toward a faith-based community than the original has been moved forward a decade and located in Detroit (though you rarely get a sense of a city on fire in 1968). Sparkle played by "American Idol" champeen Jordin Sparks has been activated in story terms so that shes not simply waiting around for things to happen to her and around her.The new "Sparkle" writes her own material which she must hide from her formidable God-fearing mother played by Whitney Houston. This is Houstons farewell; she died in February of this year after completing filming. The character of the mother is meant to be a heartbroken vocalist wannabe who chased her dreams of glory when she was younger but ran into bad luck and worse men. At one point in "Sparkle" one of her daughters confronts her about finding her some nights "laid up in your own vomit." The line stings and though Houstons character refutes it clearly its a link to Houstons own tabloid fodder image. In the film Houston sings "His Eye is On the Sparrow" at an appropriately melodramatic point in the story. Its a fitting reminder of why Houston whose voice was coarse-grained but still powerful at the time of filming became a sensation in the first place.How has "Sparkle" the showbiz myth changed since 76? No longer are there lines of dialogue such as the daughter lecturing her mother "We dont have to be slaves to the white establishment anymore" Mother was a maid in the original; in the remake shes a prosperous retail employee and active woman of the church living well but sternly until she learns to loosen up and let the offspring find themselves. Its absurd how long the daughters are able to keep their rising fame and sneaking-out-at-night a secret from their protector. But we dont enjoy films like "Sparkle" for their documentary realism.I appreciate how director Akil allows even the heinous characters such as Mike Epps self-hating comedian a moment of insight or revelation amid the story basics. Theres a well-written dinner-table scene wherein Sister (Carmen Ejogo) brings the Crisco-slick comedian home to meet her family. They smell a rat but Epps knows just how to play him without tipping his hand too early or too often about the brutalities to come.Sparks as Sparkle has a warm and pleasing screen quality. Shes a tad bland but so is the character as written. Shes meant to blow everybody away in the finale but heres another thing about "Sparkle" It actually holds back in terms of technique and dramatic builds. That restraint may hinder it at the box office but director Akil knows how to give his actors space and time to get a few things going on their own. Also theres a great simple tracking shot along a line of listening booths at a Detroit record store and if youre old enough to remember those days you may find that shot as moving as anything Houston or Sparks manages in this entertaining remix.mjphillipstribune.comSparkle -- 3 starsMPAA rating PG-13 (for mature thematic content involving domestic abuse and drug material and for some violence language and smoking)Running time 151Opens Friday MORE`I Believe We Killed Jordans DadPain relievers What are the differences?Gutierrezs Tax Bill Proves That Miracles Still Do Happen Princess Grace`s Fatal Crash Her Daughter`s AccountLife Skill 201 Washing a baseball cap10 reasons why you want the job Related LinksRelated ArticlesLawless rules with violence ... (AP Photo/TriStar Pictures - Sony Alicia Gbur) The 1976 film "Sparkle" a Supremes-inspired bit of black cinema starring Irene Cara is remembered fondly by African-American audiences some of whom may have created false yet warming memories of how good the movie really was.The cult classic boasted a strong performance by Lonette McKee and one of the best movie soundtracks youll find thanks to Curtis Mayfield and Aretha Franklin. Otherwise it was cheesy poorly lit and unremarkable.One thing the movie needed was a real spit-shine and "Sparkle" gets just that in a remake starring "American Idol" winner Jordin Sparks and Whitney Houston in her final movie role. Itll be difficult for some original "Sparkle" enthusiasts to even consider a new take. But this version improves on the original in nearly every way except the music -- obviously key in a music-based story.But how do you top Franklin and Mayfield? You dont.The entertainingly melodramatic "Sparkle" directed by Salim Akil moves the 1960s action from Harlem to Detroit where budding music trio Sister amp; Her Sisters is coming up through the music scene.Theres sweet sister Sparkle (Sparks) sexy sister Sister (Carmen Ejogo) and brainy sister Delores (Tika Sumpter) who regularly sneak out of the house to sing at local nightclubs after disapproving Mama Emma (Houston) falls asleep. Emma once tried making it as a singer and it almost ruined her.The confident Sister fronts the group singing songs written by Sparkle who yearns to be a star but lacks the nerve to step out in front.Stix (Derek Luke) who calls himself the next Berry Gordy latches onto the women and has eyes for Sparkle. Sister has two sets of eyes on her nice-guy Levi (Omari Hardwick) and flashy but hateful Satin (Mike Epps) a comedian who abuses Sister and gets her hooked on drugs tearing the group apart.What happens is tragic and its also a major plot change that fans of the original will either love or hate. Sparks in her big-screen debut is a comforting presence as a star waiting to be born and not too much is demanded of her. The heavy lifting is left to Ejogo in a role that should make her a star and Epps who perfectly plays his smarmy character with relish.And what of Houston in her final role in a casting choice that drew bittersweet "Sparkle" headlines after her death? The legendary singer handles her smallish maternal role expertly though her singing contributions are less than stellar. Theres no trace that she wouldnt live to see the movie open so dont bother looking. But when when Houstons character utters "was my life not enough of a cautionary tale for you?" viewers are lifted right out of the movie and into Houstons own tragic tale. A line about her character lying in vomit has the same impact.Director Akil employs some great stylistic touches throughout and knows how to stage a great if tumultuous dinner scene."Sparkle" will draw immediate though unfair comparisons to "Dreamgirls" which made it to the big screen first. But its worth noting the source material the original "Sparkle" was released five years before "Dreamgirls" hit Broadway.Energetic colorful and packed with strong performances and musical numbers good enough to get by "Sparkle" beams brightly.SPARKLEThree and a half stars out of four  Rating PG-13  Run time 156  Content Mature thematic content involving domestic abuse and drug material and some violence language and smoking Kevin C.
